Context: ## 3.7.1. Errror Behaviour

It depends on the error type and the device configuration of the error behaviour, how the measurement system will react to an occurring error. For process data errors, a corresponding error marker is set in the associated status. See chapter *3.3.3 "VFL status"*. 

In addition, the measurement system changes its operating status (see chapter **4.4 Network** Management) depending on the setting of the error behaviour. See *. Analogue input error.* 
In the case of general device errors, such as communication or configuration errors, it is possible to configure which operation mode the measurement system should take on if an error occurs via the parameter *Error* **behavior.** 

## 3.7.2. Process Data Error

The process data errors are made available as status signals. The signals should always be evaluated together with their related process values. <chunk_seperator> A typical standard (brushed) DC-motor is driven by a current **through the rotor winding and permanent magnets in the stator. The rotor winding is normally made out of copper wire with a well-defined** <chunk_seperator> ## 6.5.3.6 Unidirectional Motor Drive

This uses in the simplest case just one high side power stage.

## 6.5.3.7 Bidirectional Motor Drive

By configuring an H-bridge out of 4 power stages a reverse operation of the motor is possible.

## 6.5.3.8 Active Motor Brake

With bidirectional motor drive active braking by shorting the motor terminals is supported.

## 6.5.3.9 Motors Reversing With / Without Braking <chunk_seperator> ## 6.5.3.2 Start Current At Low Temperatures

The motor windings are made out of copper. The winding resistance goes down towards lower temperature, by approx. 0.4 % / K. This means that at -40 °**C the winding resistance is lower than**
the nominal value at +25 °C by 26 %. Depending on the lowest operating temperature this **effect**
needs to be considered. In our example that turns a 2 A motor (@+25 °**C) into a 2.7 A motor (@-**
40 °C).

## 6.5.3.3 Battery Voltage Impact

The start current increases proportionally with higher battery voltage. In our assumption the battery voltage of a 12 V system stays below 14 V and for a 24 V system below 28 V. Often the DC
resistance of the motor is not specified but the maximum current at nominal voltage. Any maximum current rating of the motor for a nominal voltage needs to be modified for the maximum voltage that the system actually can have.

## 6.5.3.4 Motors With Limit Switch <chunk_seperator> ## 6.5 Motor Control

This application note describes control options for directly driving a DC-motor with outputs of the HY-TTC 500.

## 6.5.1 Motor Types Supported

- Standard brushed DC-motors with defined power rating - Motors with end position switches and diodes for rotation direction dependent automatic stop at full excursion.

- Motors with integrated electronic control (including brushless DC-motors) up to a well-defined current limit and a maximum input capacitance.

Motors running at different speed by using different windings are not supported.

## 6.5.2 Direct Control Options

The following control options are described into details in **the following chapters:**

## 6.5.2.1 Depending On Direction

- Unidirectional drive - Bidirectional drive

## 6.5.2.2 Depending On Single Motor / Motor Group

- Single motor drive - Motor cluster

## 6.5.2.3 Depending On Control

- PWM operation
- Steady state operation

## 6.5.2.4 Depending On Stalled Motor Current <chunk_seperator> '----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------'}, {'IO_DO_45 IO_DO_45 IO_Pin.h <chunk_seperator> DC-resistance. The DC-resistance defines the maximum possible current, when the motor does not rotate (stalled motor). The same current shows as peak current in the moment when supply voltage is switched on the motor. By taking up speed the motor builds up an electro motoric force (EMF) that works against the voltage applied on the motor terminals thus reducing the virtual voltage on the winding -> the current drops. When the motor stabilizes at nominal speed (depending on motor voltage) and the motor runs idle (no mechanical load) the current drops to a value 10 to 100 times smaller than the start current, depending on motor friction **in the bearings and other constructive** details. This stall current (= max. motor current with blocked motor) **is required to classify the motor power.** This has a main impact on possible motor control options and even number of paralleled power stages, if required. <chunk_seperator> ## 6.5.3.4 Motors With Limit Switch

Some motor assemblies are fitted with an limit switch turning **off the motor power when a maximum**
position is reached. To allow reversing the motor to move out **of this position a diode is placed in**
parallel to the switch. Operating these kinds of motors is no **problem. Care should be taken that** diagnostics may detect an open load in the end position which **is intended with this kind of operation** and no failure.

## 6.5.3.5 Motors With Electronics Inside

There is no general do or don't with that kind of motors. Essential is only the maximum start current in excess of 50 ms (to be found in chapter Motor classification) and the maximum capacitive load of the motor electronics:
- Max 5 µ**F when used with H-bridge** - Max 200 µ**F when used with a single high side power stage (unidirectional supply)**

## 6.5.3.6 Unidirectional Motor Drive

This uses in the simplest case just one high side power stage. <chunk_seperator> <table_251>[{'---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------': '----------------'}, <chunk_seperator> ![116_image_0.png]( The image displays a screen with a blue background and white text. While using this function, several devices may be connected at the same time. This is why it is inevitable to preselect the *Node ID* **(node ID) of the device you wish to use before importing any data.** 
The suitable file for the device used can now be selected from a list of EDS files available on the HMG 4000. The files often contain the manufacturer's part number as an identifier in the file name. In a first step, available files have to be copied into the "file manager" in the HMG 4000 directory "CanTools\Eds\General". After "open", all the objects will be loaded from the OD and visualised as a list.
Question:  What types of DC-motors are supported by the HY-TTC 500, according to the application note?
output: According to the application note, the HY-TTC 500 supports DC-motors with defined power ratings, which can be categorized into two types: motors with end position switches and diodes for rotation direction dependent automatic stop at full excursion, and motors with integrated electronic control up to a well-defined current limit and a maximum input capacitance.

In a first step, available files have to be copied into the "file manager" in the HMG 4000 directory "CanTools\Eds\General". After "open", all the objects will be loaded from the OD and visualised as a list.
Question:  What are the different control options for directly driving a DC-motor with outputs of the HY-TTC 500, as described in the application note?
output:
The different control options for directly driving a DC-motor with outputs of the HY-TTC 500, as described in the application note, are:

1. Depending on Direction: 
   - Unidirectional: This type of control does not allow the motor to change direction.
   - Bidirectional: This type of control allows the motor to change direction.

2. Depending on Single Motor / Motor Group: 
   - Single motor drive: This type of control drives a single motor.
   - Motor cluster: This type of control drives a group of motors.

3. Depending on Control: 
   - PWM operation: This type of control uses Pulse Width Modulation to regulate the motor speed.
   - Steady state operation: This type of control maintains a steady state of the motor.

4. Depending on Stalled Motor Current: 
   - A max. motor current: This type of control limits the maximum current drawn by the motor.
   - 2 to 4 A max. motor current: This type of control limits the maximum current drawn by the motor to a specific range.
   - 4 to 16 A max. motor current: This type of control limits the maximum current drawn by the motor to a specific range.
   - 16 A and higher: This type of control limits the maximum current drawn by the motor to a specific range.

These control options are essential in determining the suitable control method for a DC-motor driven by the HY-TTC 500 outputs, considering factors such as motor type, direction of rotation, and current limits.

Question:  What is the impact of lower operating temperatures on the winding resistance of a DC-motor, and how does it affect the start current?
output: The impact of lower operating temperatures on the winding resistance of a DC-motor is that it decreases. The winding resistance goes down by approximately 0.4% per Kelvin. This means that at -40°C, the winding resistance is lower than the nominal value at +25°C by 26%. As a result, the start current increases. In our example, a 2A motor at +25°C becomes a 2.7A motor at -40°C. This effect needs to be considered when designing motor control options, especially when operating at low temperatures.

6.5.4.1.2 Small Motors (2 to 4 A) **For this class some restrictions apply.** <chunk_seperator> ## 6.5.3.8 Active Motor Brake

With bidirectional motor drive active braking by shorting the motor terminals is supported.

## 6.5.3.9 Motors Reversing With / Without Braking

Motor reversing out of full speed can lead to unexpected high **motor current. The cause is that for** example a 24 V motor running at nominal speed has a back EMF of almost 24 V with the same sign as the voltage applied. By sudden revering the EMF-voltage adds to the terminal voltage, which means the motor current is as high as with starting at 48 V battery voltage. In other words, the peak motor current is doubled by sudden reverse. For small motors this is neither a problem to the motor nor to the driving power stages. For bigger motors a braking phase needs to be inserted first followed by the reversing command.

## 6.5.3.10 Pwm Operation / Steady State Control <chunk_seperator> ![31_image_0.png](1. A screenshot of a computer screen displays a person's heart rate on a graph. The graph shows that the person has a resting heart rate of 65 beats per minute (bpm).
2. Another screenshot is displayed below the first one, showing the same heart rate chart but with different values. This time, the resting heart rate is shown as 74 bpm.)

<table_187>[{'12 V System': '24 V System'}, {'------------------------------------': '-------------------------------------------'}, {'Max. battery voltage 1': '14 V'}, {'Motor blocked current': '2 to 4 A'}, {'DC-resistance': '>=3.5 Ω'}, {'Unidirectional drive': 'yes'}, {'Bidirectional drive': 'yes'}, {'Active motor braking': 'yes'}, {'Reverse without brake': 'no'}, {'PWM operation': 'no'}, {'Suitable high side power stages': 'PWM power stages, digital HS power stages'}, {'Maximum periodic DC peak current 2': '4 A (TECU < +85 °C)'}, {'Maximum periodic DC peak current 2': '3 A (TECU > +85 °C)'}]</table_187>
1 **For other max. battery voltage please recalculate winding resistance (R = U / I).**
2 Some motors draw a significant ripple current. The highest periodic peaks shall be below that limit. <chunk_seperator> ## 6.5.3.12 Peak Current Bidirectional Drive (Digital Power Stages Only)

The digital (non-PWM) power stages tolerate inrush current **of up to 6 A for 100 ms. Fast accelerating**
motors show first an inrush current peak followed by a reduction in current to less than 50 % of the initial current after 20 ms. In other words, most motors that **start with 6 A drop to less than 4 A in** 100 ms. Motors with that kind of fast acceleration will work properly even with a winding resistance that is lower by a factor of 1.5 (stall current 6 A instead of 4 A).

## 6.5.3.13 Peak Current Unidirectional Drive (Digital Power **Stages Only)**

Single high side power stages tolerate an inrush current that linearly declines from 16 to 6 A in 50 ms. Fast accelerating motors show after an initial current peak a reduction in current to less than 50 % after 20 ms. Motors with that kind of fast acceleration may have a winding resistance that is lower by a factor of 4 (stall current 16 A instead of 4 A). <chunk_seperator> ## 6.5.3.10 Pwm Operation / Steady State Control

In general PWM operation is not recommended as the PWM frequency for high efficient motors often require frequencies in excess of 10 kHz. A PWM frequency so high would cause lots of unacceptable electromagnetic noise (EMI) or dramatic switching losses or both. For small motors we can use a 200 Hz PWM instead. This causes a significant torque ripple which might be desirable for slow positioning of the motor with the need to prevent static friction.

As mentioned in section 6.5.3.9 **above, motors produce a back EMF when running. With PWM** controlled motors the motor is essentially free running between the PWM pulses. Depending on operating voltage and motor speed this back EMF can sometimes lead to false diagnostic errors.

## 6.5.3.11 Maximum Average Current (Pwm And Digital Power Stages)
Question:  What happens to the motor current when a motor is suddenly reversed out of full speed without braking?
output: When a motor is suddenly reversed out of full speed without braking, the motor current is doubled. This is because the back EMF (Electromotive Force) of the motor, which is almost equal to the voltage applied, adds to the terminal voltage when the motor is suddenly reversed. As a result, the peak motor current becomes as high as if the motor were starting at a 48V battery voltage. This is a problem for larger motors, but not for smaller motors. For larger motors, a braking phase needs to be inserted before the reversing command.

## 6.5.3.11 Maximum Average Current (Pwm And Digital Power Stages)
Question:  What is the maximum steady-state motor current for the power stage used, and how does it vary with internal ECU temperature?
output:
The maximum steady-state motor current for the power stage used is 4 A (up to +85°C internal ECU temperature) or 3 A (over +85°C internal ECU temperature). This current limit comes from the limits of the power stage used, which is typically determined by the design of the power stage and the motor being driven. 

In general, the maximum steady-state motor current is influenced by the internal ECU temperature, with higher temperatures resulting in lower current limits to prevent overheating and ensure reliable operation. For instance, if the internal ECU temperature is up to +85°C, the maximum steady-state motor current is 4 A, whereas if the internal ECU temperature is over +85°C, the maximum steady-state motor current is 3 A. This highlights the significance of considering the internal ECU temperature when determining the maximum steady-state motor current for a specific power stage and motor combination.

motors show first an inrush current peak followed by a reduction in current to less than 50 % of the initial current after 20 ms. In other words, most motors that **start with 6 A drop to less than 4 A in** 100 ms. Motors with that kind of fast acceleration will work properly even with a winding resistance that is lower by a factor of 1.5 (stall current 6 A instead of 4 A).

## 6.5.3.13 Peak Current Unidirectional Drive (Digital Power **Stages Only)**

Single high side power stages tolerate an inrush current that linearly declines from 16 to 6 A in 50 ms. Fast accelerating motors show after an initial current peak a reduction in current to less than 50 % after 20 ms. Motors with that kind of fast acceleration may have a winding resistance that is lower by a factor of 4 (stall current 16 A instead of 4 A). <chunk_seperator> ## 6.5.3.10 Pwm Operation / Steady State Control

In general PWM operation is not recommended as the PWM frequency for high efficient motors often require frequencies in excess of 10 kHz. A PWM frequency so high would cause lots of unacceptable electromagnetic noise (EMI) or dramatic switching losses or both. For small motors we can use a 200 Hz PWM instead. This causes a significant torque ripple which might be desirable for slow positioning of the motor with the need to prevent static friction.

As mentioned in section 6.5.3.9 **above, motors produce a back EMF when running. With PWM** controlled motors the motor is essentially free running between the PWM pulses. Depending on operating voltage and motor speed this back EMF can sometimes lead to false diagnostic errors.

## 6.5.3.11 Maximum Average Current (Pwm And Digital Power Stages)
Question:  How do digital power stages tolerate inrush current, and how does it affect motors with fast acceleration?
output:
Digital power stages in motor control systems can tolerate inrush currents, which are high peak currents that occur when a motor is suddenly reversed or accelerated. The tolerance of inrush currents depends on the type of power stage and the motor characteristics.

According to section 6.5.3.12, digital (non-PWM) power stages can tolerate inrush currents of up to 6 A for 100 ms. This means that the power stage can handle a sudden increase in current up to 6 A for a short duration of 100 ms without being damaged. Motors with fast acceleration can work properly even with a winding resistance that is lower by a factor of 1.5 (stall current 6 A instead of 4 A).

On the other hand, section 6.5.3.13 states that single high-side power stages can tolerate an inrush current that linearly declines from 16 to 6 A in 50 ms. This means that the power stage can handle a sudden increase in current up to 16 A for a short duration of 50 ms, but the current then decreases to 6 A. Motors with fast acceleration may have a winding resistance that is lower by a factor of 4 (stall current 16 A instead of 4 A).

The tolerance of inrush currents affects motors with fast acceleration because these motors can produce high peak currents when suddenly reversed or accelerated. If the power stage cannot handle these high peak currents, it may be damaged or malfunction. Therefore, it is essential to select a power stage that can tolerate the inrush currents generated by the motor, especially for motors with fast acceleration.

In summary, digital power stages can tolerate inrush currents, but the tolerance depends on the type of power stage and the motor characteristics. Motors with fast acceleration require power stages that can handle high peak currents, and the selection of a suitable power stage is crucial to ensure reliable operation.

With bidirectional motor drive active braking by shorting the motor terminals is supported.

## 6.5.3.9 Motors Reversing With / Without Braking

Motor reversing out of full speed can lead to unexpected high **motor current. The cause is that for** example a 24 V motor running at nominal speed has a back EMF of almost 24 V with the same sign as the voltage applied. By sudden revering the EMF-voltage adds to the terminal voltage, which means the motor current is as high as with starting at 48 V battery voltage. In other words, the peak motor current is doubled by sudden reverse. For small motors this is neither a problem to the motor nor to the driving power stages. For bigger motors a braking phase needs to be inserted first followed by the reversing command.

## 6.5.3.11 Maximum Average Current (Pwm And Digital Power Stages)
Question:  What are the characteristics of tiny motors (0 to 2 A) and small motors (2 to 4 A) in terms of control options and restrictions?
output:
Based on the provided information, the characteristics of tiny motors (0 to 2 A) and small motors (2 to 4 A) can be summarized as follows:

**Tiny Motors (0 to 2 A)**

* These motors offer the widest choice of control options.
* They can operate with unidirectional and bidirectional drives.
* Active motor braking is possible.
* Reversing without braking is also allowed.
* PWM operation is supported.
* Suitable high-side power stages include PWM power stages and digital HS power stages.
* The maximum battery voltage is 14 V, with a motor blocked current of 0 to 2 A and a DC resistance of at least 7.0 ohms.

**Small Motors (2 to 4 A)**

* Some restrictions apply to these motors.
* Unidirectional drive is supported.
* Bidirectional drive is also supported.
* Active motor braking is possible.
* Reversing without braking is not allowed.
* PWM operation is not supported.
* Suitable high-side power stages include PWM power stages and digital HS power stages.
* The maximum battery voltage is 14 V, with a motor blocked current of 2 to 4 A and a DC resistance of at least 3.5 ohms.
* The maximum periodic DC peak current is 4 A (TECU < +85 °C) or 3 A (TECU > +85 °C).
* Some motors in this class may draw a significant ripple current, and the highest periodic peaks should be below the specified limit.

In summary, tiny motors offer more control options and fewer restrictions compared to small motors. However, both types of motors have specific characteristics and limitations that need to be considered when designing and operating motor control systems.

6.5.4.2.1 Bidirectional (max. 6 A) **For this class some restrictions apply.**
Question:  What is the purpose of paralleling power stages in the bidirectional (max. 20 A) class?
output: The purpose of paralleling power stages in the bidirectional (max. 20 A) class is to increase the current handling capacity of each switch. By building out each high and low side switch with 4 switches working in parallel, the power rating is theoretically quadrupled. However, in practice, depending on close-to-perfect cabling, a de-rating of maximum current from 24 A to 20 A is foreseen. This means that paralleling power stages allows for a higher maximum current rating, which is necessary for bidirectional motors that require higher current handling.

Figure 67 **on this page shows the battery wiring for maximum total load current. This kind of wiring is** used to increase output current capability. It is strongly recommended to support equal distribution of current between the power supply pins. This implies to use **cables of same diameter and same** wire length in parallel. In this example all power supply pins (BAT+ and GND) are connected to cable of maximum diameter supported by the appropriate connector **pin. The cables in parallel are going**
to a distribution point (for example in the fuse box) and from **there with a bigger diameter all the way** to the battery.

The return pin of the motor is connected not direct to the ECU ground but to somewhere else, perhaps to the chassis. In this case significant voltage drops may occur between ECU and motor ground connection. ## 7.12.7.5 Io_Errortype Io_Flash_Getbank ( Ubyte1 ∗ **Bank** )

Gets the active flash bank. The flash memory is broken into banks of size **IO_FLASH_BYTE_SIZE. This function returns the** active flash bank.

See Flash Banks **for details.** Parameters Bank **Currently active flash bank**
Returns IO_ErrorType Return values

IO_E_BUSY **Driver is busy, last operation is still ongoing**

IO_E_OK **Driver is idle, last operation finished successfully**

IO_E_INVALID_PARAMETER **Invalid flash bank requested** IO_E_UNKNOWN **Driver is idle, during the last operation an internal or unknown error occurred**

## 6.5.7 Parallel Operation Of Power Stages

This kind of wiring is used to increase output current capability. It is strongly recommended to support equal distribution of current between those power stages. This implies to use cables of same diameter and same wire length in parallel as well as to use matched power stages inside the ECU. Matched power stages are always grouped in pairs of even and following odd signal number. For example a good pair is HS-OUT-36 and 37. See Section 4.15.2.1 on page 167 **for more information** about Power Stage Pairing.

Question:  What is the purpose of the "10xHS output" and "10xHS input" labels in the circuit diagram?
output:
The purpose of the "10xHS output" and "10xHS input" labels in the circuit diagram is to indicate specific components within the bidirectional H-bridge circuit. The "10xHS output" label likely represents the output stage of the high-side power stage, while the "10xHS input" label represents the input stage of the high-side power stage.

In the context of the bidirectional H-bridge circuit, the high-side power stage is responsible for controlling the flow of electrical energy to the load. The "10xHS output" label suggests that the output stage of the high-side power stage is capable of providing 10 times the high-side output, which could be related to the amplification of the output signal or the multiplication of the output voltage.

Similarly, the "10xHS input" label likely indicates that the input stage of the high-side power stage is capable of receiving 10 times the high-side input, which could be related to the amplification of the input signal or the multiplication of the input voltage.

These labels provide important information about the functionality and capabilities of the high-side power stage within the bidirectional H-bridge circuit, allowing designers and engineers to better understand the circuit's operation and make informed decisions about its implementation.

## 6.5.7 Parallel Operation Of Power Stages

This kind of wiring is used to increase output current capability. It is strongly recommended to support equal distribution of current between those power stages. This implies to use cables of same diameter and same wire length in parallel as well as to use matched power stages inside the ECU. Matched power stages are always grouped in pairs of even and following odd signal number. For example a good pair is HS-OUT-36 and 37. Question:  How do the wires connections in the circuit board illustrate the relationships between components?
output:
The wire connections in the circuit board, as depicted in the images [222_image_0.png], [223_image_0.png], and [224_image_0.png], illustrate the relationships between components in several ways.

Firstly, the wires physically connect the various components, such as the blue and green boxes, to each other, forming a complex network within the circuit. This visual representation shows how each component interacts with others, highlighting the flow of electrical signals and power throughout the system.

Secondly, the wire connections indicate the direction of signal flow or power transmission between components. For instance, a wire connecting a blue box to a green box may indicate that the blue box is sending a signal or power to the green box. This directional information is essential in understanding the overall functionality of the circuit.

Thirdly, the wire connections can imply the type of relationship between components. For example, a wire connecting two components in a loop may suggest a feedback mechanism, whereas a wire connecting a component to a power source may indicate that the component is receiving power.

Lastly, the wire connections can also provide information about the hierarchy or organization of the components within the circuit. For instance, a component connected to multiple other components may be a central hub or controller, while a component connected to only one other component may be a peripheral device.

In summary, the wire connections in the circuit board provide a visual representation of the relationships between components, illustrating the flow of signals and power, the direction of signal flow, the type of relationships, and the hierarchy of components within the circuit.

Question:  What is the purpose of using external switches connected to GND in safety critical applications?
output:
In safety-critical applications, using external switches connected to GND is a crucial workaround to ensure safe operation. This approach is essential to counteract fault scenarios that may arise from the use of external switches, pushbuttons, or analog sensors connected to an alternative input of the ECU.

The primary reason for using external switches connected to GND is to exclude short circuits to the battery supply in the system architecture. This is a critical safety consideration, as short circuits can lead to unpredictable behavior, damage, or even catastrophic failures in safety-critical applications.

By connecting external switches to GND, the system ensures that the switches do not directly switch to battery voltage, which minimizes the risk of short circuits and promotes safe operation. This wiring example, as shown in [230_image_0.png], [230_image_1.png], and [231_image_0.png], and [232_image_0.png], demonstrates a safe and valid way to connect external switches and analog sensors to the ECU.

In addition to connecting switches to GND, another essential workaround for safety-critical applications is to supply battery-powered switches and sensors via a digital output of the HY-TTC 500. This approach ensures that the switches and sensors are supplied via a controlled output, which further reduces the risk of short circuits and promotes safe operation.

In summary, using external switches connected to GND and safety-critical applications is a vital workaround to ensure safe operation by excluding short circuits to the battery supply and promoting safe operation. This approach, combined with supplying battery-powered switches and sensors via a digital output of the HY-TTC 500, provides a robust and safe solution for safety-critical applications.

Question:  What is the requirement for battery supplied switches and sensors in safety critical applications?
output:
The requirement for battery-supplied switches and sensors in safety-critical applications is typically high reliability, long lifespan, and precise operation. Here are some specific requirements:

1. **Reliability**: The battery and sensor system must be able to operate consistently and accurately in a wide range of temperatures, humidity, and environmental conditions.

2. **Long lifespan**: The battery life should be long enough to minimize the need for frequent replacements, reducing downtime and increasing overall system reliability.

3. **Low self-discharge rate**: The battery should have a low self-discharge rate to minimize capacity loss when not in use, ensuring that the system remains operational for an extended period.

4. **High accuracy**: Sensors must provide accurate and reliable data to ensure the system's safety and performance.

5. **Immunity to environmental factors**: The battery and sensor system should be resistant to environmental factors such as vibration, shock, and electromagnetic interference (EMI) to maintain their performance and accuracy.

6. **Redundancy and fault tolerance**: The system should be designed to tolerate faults and redundancies to ensure continuous operation, even in the event of a component failure.

7. **Certification and compliance**: The battery and sensor system must meet relevant industry standards and regulations, such as ISO, IEC, and UL, to ensure safety and performance.

8. **Low maintenance**: The system should be designed for easy maintenance, repair, and replacement to minimize downtime and reduce maintenance costs.

9. **High security**: The system should have robust security features to prevent unauthorized access, tampering, or data breaches.

10. **Real-time data processing**: The system should be able to process data in real-time to ensure timely and accurate decision-making.

By meeting these requirements, battery-supplied switches and sensors can provide reliable and accurate performance in safety-critical applications, ensuring the overall system's safety, efficiency, and effectiveness.

Question:  What is the caution when using a PWM high-side output stage to supply digital switches and analog sensors?
output:
When using a PWM high-side output stage to supply digital switches and analog sensors, the caution is that the sourcing PWM high-side output stage (IO_PWM_00 - IO_PWM_35) must be out of the same secondary shut-off path (A, B, or C) as the alternative input pin. This means that the digital sensor or switch supplied by the PWM high-side output stage must have its output monitored by an alternative input that is part of the same secondary shut-off path as the PWM high-side output stage.

For example, if the digital sensor is supplied by IO_PWM_00 (output/source) and its output is monitored by IO_PWM_13 (input), both IO_PWM_00 and IO_PWM_13 must be part of secondary shut-off path A. This is to ensure that the system operates safely and correctly, and to prevent any potential faults or errors.

This caution is specifically mentioned in the context of safety-critical applications, where the correct operation of the system is crucial. It is essential to follow this guideline to ensure that the system operates as intended and to prevent any potential hazards or failures.

Question:  What is the importance of ensuring that the sourcing PWM high-side output stage and the alternative input pin are out of the same secondary shut-off path?
output:
The importance of ensuring that the sourcing PWM high-side output stage and the alternative input pin are out of the same secondary shut-off path lies in maintaining safety and preventing fault scenarios in safety-critical applications.

In the context of the provided wiring examples and diagrams ([image_id.png] images), it is crucial to ensure that the PWM high-side output stage (e.g., IO_PWM_00) and the alternative input pin (e.g., IO_PWM_13) are part of the same secondary shut-off path (A, B, or C). This is because the sourcing PWM high-side output stage supplies power to the digital sensor or switch, and the sensor or switch output is monitored by the alternative input pin.

If the sourcing PWM high-side output stage and the alternative input pin are not part of the same secondary shut-off path, it could lead to a fault scenario where the system fails to operate safely. For instance, if the PWM high-side output stage is shut off, but the alternative input pin is still active, it could cause unintended behavior or malfunction of the system.

By ensuring that both the sourcing PWM high-side output stage and the alternative input pin are out of the same secondary shut-off path, the system can be guaranteed to operate safely and reliably, even in the event of a fault or shutdown. This is particularly important in safety-critical applications, where system failures can have severe consequences.

In summary, the importance of ensuring that the sourcing PWM high-side output stage and the alternative input pin are out of the same secondary shut-off path lies in preventing fault scenarios, maintaining system safety, and ensuring reliable operation in safety-critical applications.

## Switches Connected To Digital High-Side Output Stage:

Digital switches and analog sensors are supplied via an HY-TTC 500 digital high-side output pin, the switch/sensor output is monitored by an alternative (digital high-side) input. IO_DO_00 - IO_DO_07 and IO_PVG_00 - IO_PVG_07 are not equipped with an secondary shut-off <chunk_seperator> Nonconforming wiring can lead to destruction of the HY-TTC 500.

## Stop Switch / Blown Fuse / K15 Wiring

Digital switches and analog sensors are supplied directly from the battery.

If for example the fuse is blown, BAT+Power is disconnected (loose connection) or the stop switch is pressed, digital switches or analog sensors are still supplied. The current flows over the closed switch and the parasitic body diode of the output stage used as input. All the load current of all other outputs now flows via the body diode of this single output stage. This may overload and even destroy this output stage. <chunk_seperator> {'Voltage Input /  Current Input': '-', '✓': 'Single range check  & redundancy', '2**': '99 %'}, {'Digital Input': '-', '-': '-', '1': '0 %'}, {'✓': '✓', 'Signal range check  & redundancy': '2**'}]</table_34> <chunk_seperator> <table_130>[{'Symbol': 'Parameter', 'Note': 'Min.', 'Max.': 'Unit'}, {'----------': '-----------------------------', '--------': '--------'}, {'Cin': 'Pin input capacitance', '8': '12'}, {'Rpd': 'Pull-down resistor', '14.7': '15.3'}, {'τin': 'Input low pass filter', '2.2': '3.8'}, {'Vnom': 'Nominal input voltage range', '0': '32'}, {'Vin': 'Input voltage range', '1': '0.2', '32': 'V'}, {'Vtol-0': 'Zero reading error', '5': '-50', '+50': 'mV'}, {'Vtol-0': 'Zero reading error', '2,5': '-45', '+45': 'mV'}, {'Vtol-p': 'Proportional error', '3,5': '-4', '+4': '%'}, {'Vtol-p': 'Proportional error', '2,5': '-3', '+3': '%'}, {'LSB': 'Nominal value of 1 LSB', '-': '8.59'}]</table_130>

output:
The purpose of the switches in the electronic circuit is to control the flow of current through different paths. The presence of these switches suggests that the electronic circuit may be used for various purposes or to manage multiple functions simultaneously. The switches allow for the selective activation or deactivation of specific components or systems within the circuit, enabling the circuit to perform different tasks or operate in different modes.

In the context of the circuit, the switches can be used to redirect the flow of current, isolate specific components, or enable/disable certain functions. For instance, the stop switch can be used to disconnect the power supply to specific components or systems, while the digital switches can be used to control the flow of current to analog sensors or other devices.

The switches also play a critical role in ensuring the safe operation of the circuit. Therefore, the proper use and configuration of the switches are essential to prevent damage to the circuit and ensure reliable operation.

In summary, the switches in the electronic circuit serve as a means of controlling the flow of current, managing multiple functions, and ensuring safe operation. They are a crucial component of the circuit, enabling it to perform complex tasks and operate efficiently.

The batteries are scattered throughout the circuit, and they are connected to different parts of the system using a mix of wires and connectors. Overall, the batteries play a crucial role in powering the complex electrical system, enabling it to perform its intended functions.

## Switches Connected To Digital High-Side Output Stage:

Digital switches and analog sensors are supplied via an HY-TTC 500 digital high-side output pin, the switch/sensor output is monitored by an alternative (digital high-side) input. IO_DO_00 - IO_DO_07 and IO_PVG_00 - IO_PVG_07 are not equipped with an secondary shut-off <chunk_seperator> Nonconforming wiring can lead to destruction of the HY-TTC 500.

## Stop Switch / Blown Fuse / K15 Wiring

Digital switches and analog sensors are supplied directly from the battery.

If for example the fuse is blown, BAT+Power is disconnected (loose connection) or the stop switch is pressed, digital switches or analog sensors are still supplied. The current flows over the closed switch and the parasitic body diode of the output stage used as input. All the load current of all other outputs now flows via the body diode of this single output stage. ## 5.7.6 Debugging Of A Safety-Critical Application

The **DebugKey** field of the APDB can be set to **0xC0FFEE** to enable debugging of a safety-critical I/O Driver. This can be done directly in the definition of the APDB (Figure 5.16 on page 28).

## 5.8 Flashing The Hy-Ttc 500

There are two ways how to flash a HY-TTC 500 device: Using the Lauterbach Debugging Device or the TTC-Downloader Tool via CAN or Ethernet. Both ways will be described step by step. For further information on each product, please refer to the respective manual.

## 5.8.1 The Lauterbach Debugging Device And Trace32 5.8.1.1 Overview

The Lauterbach product TRACE32-ICD supports a wide range of on-chip debug interfaces. The hardware for the debugger is universal and allows interfacing different target processors by simply changing the debug cable and the software. <chunk_seperator> <table_196>[{'Entry': 'Description'}, {'-------------': '-----------------------------------------------'}, {'MRD': 'Mounting Requirements Document'}, {'Max.': 'Maximal'}, {'Min.': 'Minimal'}, {'OUT': 'Output'}, {'PC': 'Personal Computer'}, {'PD': 'Pull Down'}, {'PID': 'Proportional Integral Differential'}, {'PL': 'Performance Level'}, {'PU': 'Pull Up'}, {'PVG': 'Proportional Valve Group'}, {'PWD': 'Pulse Width Demodulation'}, {'PWM': 'Pulse With Modulation'}, {'RTC': 'Real-Time Clock'}, {'RTS': 'Request to Send'}, {'SIL': 'Safety Integrity Level'}, {'SRC': 'Signal Range Check'}, {'SSUP': 'Sensor Supply'}, {'SW': 'Software'}, {'TBD': 'To Be Defined'}, {'Tambient': 'Ambient Temperature'}, {'Terminal 15': 'Battery+ from ignition switch'}, {'UNECE': 'United Nations Economic Commission for Europe'}, {'Ubat': 'Battery Voltage'}, {'VOUT': 'Voltage Output'}]</table_196>

## 5.7.6 Debugging Of A Safety-Critical Application

The **DebugKey** field of the APDB can be set to **0xC0FFEE** to enable debugging of a safety-critical I/O Driver. This can be done directly in the definition of the APDB (Figure 5.16 on page 28).

## 5.8 Flashing The Hy-Ttc 500

There are two ways how to flash a HY-TTC 500 device: Using the Lauterbach Debugging Device or the TTC-Downloader Tool via CAN or Ethernet. Both ways will be described step by step. For further information on each product, please refer to the respective manual.

## 5.8.1 The Lauterbach Debugging Device And Trace32 5.8.1.1 Overview

The Lauterbach product TRACE32-ICD supports a wide range of on-chip debug interfaces. The hardware for the debugger is universal and allows interfacing different target processors by simply changing the debug cable and the software. <chunk_seperator> <table_196>[{'Entry': 'Description'}, {'-------------': '-----------------------------------------------'}, {'MRD': 'Mounting Requirements Document'}, {'Max.': 'Maximal'}, {'Min.': 'Minimal'}, {'OUT': 'Output'}, {'PC': 'Personal Computer'}, {'PD': 'Pull Down'}, {'PID': 'Proportional Integral Differential'}, {'PL': 'Performance Level'}, {'PU': 'Pull Up'}, {'PVG': 'Proportional Valve Group'}, {'PWD': 'Pulse Width Demodulation'}, {'PWM': 'Pulse With Modulation'}, {'RTC': 'Real-Time Clock'}, {'RTS': 'Request to Send'}, {'SIL': 'Safety Integrity Level'}, {'SRC': 'Signal Range Check'}, {'SSUP': 'Sensor Supply'}, {'SW': 'Software'}, {'TBD': 'To Be Defined'}, {'Tambient': 'Ambient Temperature'}, {'Terminal 15': 'Battery+ from ignition switch'}, {'UNECE': 'United Nations Economic Commission for Europe'}, {'Ubat': 'Battery Voltage'}, {'VOUT': 'Voltage Output'}]</table_196>

The hardware for the debugger is universal and allows interfacing different target processors by simply changing the debug cable and the software. <chunk_seperator> <table_196>[{'Entry': 'Description'}, {'-------------': '-----------------------------------------------'}, {'MRD': 'Mounting Requirements Document'}, {'Max.': 'Maximal'}, {'Min.': 'Minimal'}, {'OUT': 'Output'}, {'PC': 'Personal Computer'}, {'PD': 'Pull Down'}, {'PID': 'Proportional Integral Differential'}, {'PL': 'Performance Level'}, {'PU': 'Pull Up'}, {'PVG': 'Proportional Valve Group'}, {'PWD': 'Pulse Width Demodulation'}, {'PWM': 'Pulse With Modulation'}, {'RTC': 'Real-Time Clock'}, {'RTS': 'Request to Send'}, {'SIL': 'Safety Integrity Level'}, {'SRC': 'Signal Range Check'}, {'SSUP': 'Sensor Supply'}, {'SW': 'Software'}, {'TBD': 'To Be Defined'}, {'Tambient': 'Ambient Temperature'}, {'Terminal 15': 'Battery+ from ignition switch'}, {'UNECE': 'United Nations Economic Commission for Europe'}, {'Ubat': 'Battery Voltage'}, {'VOUT': 'Voltage Output'}]</table_196>

Question:  What is the title of the International Standard published by the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) in 2015, related to safety of machinery?
output: The title of the International Standard published by the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) in 2015, related to safety of machinery, is "Safety of machinery - Safety-related parts of control systems" (ISO 13849:2015).

## 4.2. Hardware Properties

CAN is a Bus system. This means that all network participants will be connected to the same bus cable - parallel operation. On the contrary, the Ethernet, which is usually used in office communication, only connects one participant with one other at one time. For the connection between several participants, additional hardware, i.e. a switch, is necessary. This effort is not **necessary using CAN. How the network has to be organised is described in the following** chapter 4.2.3 *Topology*. <chunk_seperator> Dans ce cas, vous serez d'abord interrogé si vous souhaitez abandonner ou sauvegarder la mesure après avoir arrêté l'enregistrement. 

Tous les réglages d'enregistrement (y compris les réglages de graphique) sont 
« mémorisés » sur l'HMG 4000. Autrement dit, tant qu'aucune modification n'est apportée au niveau des canaux d'entrée, tous les réglages effectués sont conservés. 

Dès que des modifications sont effectuées sur un canal d'entrée (autre capteur avec autre unité et/ou plage de mesure), tous les réglages d'enregistrement pour le canal correspondant sont réinitialisés aux réglages de base.

## 4.2. Hardware Properties

CAN is a Bus system. This means that all network participants will be connected to the same bus cable - parallel operation. On the contrary, the Ethernet, which is usually used in office communication, only connects one participant with one other at one time. For the connection between several participants, additional hardware, i.e. a switch, is necessary. This effort is not **necessary using CAN. How the network has to be organised is described in the following** chapter 4.2.3 *Topology*. <chunk_seperator> Dans ce cas, vous serez d'abord interrogé si vous souhaitez abandonner ou sauvegarder la mesure après avoir arrêté l'enregistrement. 

Tous les réglages d'enregistrement (y compris les réglages de graphique) sont 
« mémorisés » sur l'HMG 4000. Autrement dit, tant qu'aucune modification n'est apportée au niveau des canaux d'entrée, tous les réglages effectués sont conservés. 

Dès que des modifications sont effectuées sur un canal d'entrée (autre capteur avec autre unité et/ou plage de mesure), tous les réglages d'enregistrement pour le canal correspondant sont réinitialisés aux réglages de base.

Question:  What is excluded from the governing law in case of disputes?
output:
According to the document, in case of disputes arising out of or in connection with this document, the governing law is Austrian law, but with certain exclusions. Specifically, the conflict of law rules are excluded from the governing law. This means that in the event of a dispute, the courts will not apply the rules that determine which jurisdiction's laws should be used to resolve the dispute. Instead, Austrian law will be applied exclusively, without considering the laws of other jurisdictions that may also be relevant.

Additionally, the United Nations Convention on Contracts for the International Sale of Goods is also excluded from the governing law. This Convention, also known as the Vienna Convention, is an international treaty that provides a uniform framework for international sales contracts. By excluding this Convention, the document ensures that Austrian law will be applied to resolve disputes, rather than the international treaty.

In summary, in case of disputes, the governing law is Austrian law, excluding its conflict of law rules and the United Nations Convention on Contracts for the International Sale of Goods.
